checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes: In the proposal, PyTorch Lightning (v2.5.5) is used to implement and scale the training pipeline for a family of MLP models that approximate climate variables for climate-data compression.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: In the official Lightning docs, I did not find documentation indicating or implying weapons/military/nuclear functionality; however, Lightning’s public site includes at least one community blog post that explicitly uses the word “military” in a non-technical career context (not a software use-case).

checks.name: Restricted Entities Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
PyTorch Lightning is maintained under the Lightning-AI GitHub organization (Lightning AI), and the project is associated with Lightning AI (https://www.linkedin.com/company/pytorch-lightning?utm_source=chatgpt.com : USA) and its founder/creator William “Will” Falcon (https://www.linkedin.com/in/wfalcon?utm_source=chatgpt.com - USA).
 Non-D5

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes: In the proposal, NumPy (v2.3.4) is listed as a helper dependency for PyTorch, supporting the project’s objective of training MLP models used for climate-data compression.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: Across NumPy’s official documentation and governance pages, I found no indication or implied use-cases related to military, weapons, or nuclear applications.

checks.name: Restricted Entities Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
NumPy is maintained by the NumPy Developers community under a formal Steering Council governance model and is a sponsored project of NumFOCUS (nonprofit fiscal sponsor). 
Non-D5

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes: In the proposal, Xarray (v2025.10.1) is used to process NetCDF files as part of the workflow that prepares/handles climate datasets used for compression modeling.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: A keyword scan of Xarray’s official docs/release notes and the repository license page did not surface terms like “military”, “weapons”, or “nuclear,” and I did not see documentation implying such restricted use-cases.

checks.name: Restricted Entities Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes: Xarray is maintained by the xarray Developers under the pydata/xarray project and is a NumFOCUS sponsored project; examples of prominent maintainers/contributors include Stephan Hoyer (Google) and Julia Signell (Element 84) (https://www.linkedin.com/in/stephanhoyer?utm_source=chatgpt.com : San Francisco). Non-D5

checks.notes: In the proposal, Matplotlib (v3.10.7) is used for plotting/visualizing results and performance/metrics produced by the project’s climate-data compression modeling workflow.

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes: In the proposal, Pyinterp (v2025.11.0) is used to provide interpolation functions within the project workflow supporting ML-based scientific/climate data compression.

checks.notes: In the Pyinterp project documentation and package descriptions reviewed, I did not find stated or implied use-cases related to “military”, “weapons”, or “nuclear” (it is documented as a geoscience/scientific interpolation library).

checks.notes: Pyinterp is developed/maintained in the CNES/pangeo-pyinterp repository (affiliated with CNES – the French space agency), and CNES has an official LinkedIn presence. https://www.linkedin.com/company/cnes/?utm_source=chatgpt.com Non-D5

form_data.observations: The custom MLP models have been indicated however, the model files have not been shared. The number of trainable parameters in the proposed models is typically 10-100 million. The maximum FLOPs expected from their proposal are of the order of 10^18 using 6xNxD after training.
